SCENE+ Module

Detailed Description

The Scene and its Renderee Objects.

This module defines the objects capable to be rendered or which otherwise affect the final animation ("the renderees", see ISceneRenderee). These objects form the Animation Scene and its top objects, like Scene Meshed Objects, Lights and Cameras. The generic interface of ISceneRenderee, together with the IRndrGeneric both form the FreeWill+ basic rendering structure.

The interfaces here cover IScene and its objects: ISceneObject, ISceneCamera and ISceneLight.

How to Configure a Scene of Animation

In most cases you will just load entire scenes from an external file (see IFileLoader), however understanding the whole process may be useful.

  1. Create the Renderer Object (implements IRndrGeneric, see IRenderer for example). Use IFWDevice::CreateObject (see Creating the FreeWill+ Objects to learn how to create FreeWill+ objects).
  2. Initialise the Renderer calling IRndrGeneric::InitDisplay
  3. Call IRndrGeneric::GetBuffers to access hardware buffers and initialise them with IMeshVertexBuffer::Create and IMeshFaceBuffer::Create. Notice that the buffers must be created internally by the renderer, as they usually require low-level initialisation. Unlike most objects, they cannot be created with IFWDevice::CreateObject.
  4. Create Scene Object (implements IScene)
  5. Pass the Renderer to the Scene, calling IScene::SetRenderer
  6. At this stage you may pass the IScene object to IFileLoader::LoadScene to load all the objects from the file. In that case the scene will be complete, so omit remaining actions.
  7. To create Scene Meshed Objects (ISceneObject) use IScene::NewObject / IScene::AddObject facility functions.
  8. To add other screen objects (e.g. lights, cameras) use IScene::AddChild function.
  9. Supply meshes using ISceneObject::NewMesh or ISceneObject::AddMesh facility functions.
  10. Scene Meshed Objects, as all Renderees, implement IKineNode and so use them as a root node for the object's kinematical structure of bones.
  11. As the vertex blending facility (see Vertex Blending Support) often requires plain (single-tier) namespaces for the bones, you will often want to add each bone in the hierarchy as an additional child node for the Scene Meshed Object. Use IKineNode::AddChildEx with the bSetParentalDep parameter set to FALSE to retain the appropriate parentship of this node. In this way the child bone will behave accordingly to its position in the kinematical hierarchy and in the same time will be visible directly in the Scene Meshed Object's namespace.

Further processing goes beyond the SCENE+ module, see The Mesh Object (IMesh) and Kinematic Chains and Hierarchies.

Remarks:
All Renderees inherit after IKineNode, so IKineNode::AddChild and similar functions may be used to configure the Animation Scene. Notice that whenever facility functions are provided for creating/adding new objects (IScene::NewObject, IScene::AddObject, ISceneObject::NewMesh, ISceneObject::AddMesh) it is strongly recommended to use them due to mandatory initialisation they provide.

IScene::Render will render only the scene's direct children, any renderees further in the hierarchy must be rendered by hand. You can use IScene::AddChildEx with the bSetParentalDep parameter set to FALSE if you want to put an object twice into the structure.

How the FreeWill+ Animation Works

The IScene object hosts all the entities subject to animation or otherwise affecting the rendering, so the IScene::Render is the system main entry gate for the rendering. Calling it usually requires some preliminary as well as finalising steps, see External Module: FWRender for details.

To achieve the animation you have to create the renderer object, set up the animation scene (see previous section), create a number of Animation Actions (see ACTION+ Module) and repeatedly call IScene::Render (together with preliminary and finalising if required), supplying the current time [UNDOCUMENTED HOW TO DO IT]. You can also call any other renderees to render (ISceneRenderee::Render), what may be indispensable in case they are not direct children of the IScene Animation Scene.

See also:
RNDR+ Module

Implementation Remarks

All the interfaces have standard implementation with full support as the kinematical chain links, thus "incorporating" the bones, see FreeWillPlus::SceneObject, FreeWillPlus::SceneLight, FreeWillPlus::SceneCamera, FreeWillPlus::Scene.
